snippet: Charlene Wise’s autistic son was too terrified to go trick-or-treating in 2014. But Delquon, 6, who has also been diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity and obsessive compulsive disorders, took to the streets with glee this past Halloween, another sign of his newfound grasp of the world.
abstract: Kennedy Child Study Center, an affiliate of Catholic Charities Archdiocese of New York, one of the agencies supported by the Neediest Cases fund, provides Charlene Wise with services and $325 to buy winter clothes for her 6-year-old son Delquon Matthews, who suffers from autism.
lead_paragraph: Charlene Wise’s autistic son was too terrified to go trick-or-treating in 2014. But Delquon, 6, who has also been diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity and obsessive compulsive disorders, took to the streets with glee this past Halloween, another sign of his newfound grasp of the world.

headline.print_headline: A Mother Marks Her Son’s Progress in Confidence and Clearer Speech
headline.main: A Mother Marks Her Son’s Progress by His Confidence and Clear Speech

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
